text: SECT. I. OF THE ORIGIN OF OUR IDEAS.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: All the perceptions of the human mind resolve themselves into two
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: distinct kinds, which I shall call IMPRESSIONS and IDEAS. The difference
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: betwixt these consists in the degrees of force and liveliness, with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which they strike upon the mind, and make their way into our thought
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: or consciousness. Those perceptions, which enter with most force and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: violence, we may name impressions: and under this name I comprehend
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: all our sensations, passions and emotions, as they make their first
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: appearance in the soul. By ideas I mean the faint images of these in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: thinking and reasoning; such as, for instance, are all the perceptions
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: excited by the present discourse, excepting only those which arise from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the sight and touch, and excepting the immediate pleasure or uneasiness
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: it may occasion. I believe it will not be very necessary to employ many
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: words in explaining this distinction. Every one of himself will readily
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: perceive the difference betwixt feeling and thinking. The common degrees
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of these are easily distinguished; though it is not impossible but in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: particular instances they may very nearly approach to each other. Thus
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in sleep, in a fever, in madness, or in any very violent emotions of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: soul, our ideas may approach to our impressions, As on the other hand
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: it sometimes happens, that our impressions are so faint and low, that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: we cannot distinguish them from our ideas. But notwithstanding this near
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: resemblance in a few instances, they are in general so very different,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that no-one can make a scruple to rank them under distinct heads, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: assign to each a peculiar name to mark the difference [Footnote 1.].
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: had perverted it, in making it stand for all our
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: perceptions. By the terms of impression I would not be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: perceptions themselves; for which there is no particular
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: name either in the English or any other language, that I
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: know of.]
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: There is another division of our perceptions, which it will be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: convenient to observe, and which extends itself both to our impressions
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and ideas. This division is into SIMPLE and COMPLEX. Simple perceptions
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: or impressions and ideas are such as admit of no distinction nor
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: separation. The complex are the contrary to these, and may be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: distinguished into parts. Though a particular colour, taste, and smell,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: are qualities all united together in this apple, it is easy to perceive
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: they are not the same, but are at least distinguishable from each other.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Having by these divisions given an order and arrangement to our objects,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: we may now apply ourselves to consider with the more accuracy their
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: qualities and relations. The first circumstance, that strikes my eye, is
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the great resemblance betwixt our impressions and ideas in every other
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: particular, except their degree of force and vivacity. The one seem to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: be in a manner the reflexion of the other; so that all the perceptions
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of the mind are double, and appear both as impressions and ideas. When
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: I shut my eyes and think of my chamber, the ideas I form are exact
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: representations of the impressions I felt; nor is there any circumstance
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of the one, which is not to be found in the other. In running over my
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: other perceptions, I find still the same resemblance and representation.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Ideas and impressions appear always to correspond to each other. This
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: circumstance seems to me remarkable, and engages my attention for a
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: moment.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the first appearance, and that I must make use of the distinction of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: perceptions into simple and complex, to limit this general decision,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that all our ideas and impressions are resembling. I observe, that many
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas. I can imagine to myself such a city as the New Jerusalem, whose
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: real and just proportions?
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: I perceive, therefore, that though there is in general a great,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: resemblance betwixt our complex impressions and ideas, yet the rule is
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: not universally true, that they are exact copies of each other. We may
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: next consider how the case stands with our simple, perceptions. After
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the most accurate examination, of which I am capable, I venture to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: affirm, that the rule here holds without any exception, and that every
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: simple idea has a simple impression, which resembles it, and every
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: simple impression a correspondent idea. That idea of red, which we form
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in the dark, and that impression which strikes our eyes in sun-shine,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: differ only in degree, not in nature. That the case is the same with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: all our simple impressions and ideas, it is impossible to prove by a
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: particular enumeration of them. Every one may satisfy himself in this
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: point by running over as many as he pleases. But if any one should deny
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: this universal resemblance, I know no way of convincing him, but by
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: idea, or a simple idea, that has not a correspondent impression. If he
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: does not answer this challenge, as it is certain he cannot, we may from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: his silence and our own observation establish our conclusion.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Thus we find, that all simple ideas and impressions resemble each other;
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and as the complex are formed from them, we may affirm in general,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that these two species of perception are exactly correspondent. Having
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: curious to find some other of their qualities. Let us consider how they
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: stand with regard to their existence, and which of the impressions and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas are causes, and which effects.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: treatise; and therefore we shall here content ourselves with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: establishing one general proposition, THAT ALL OUR SIMPLE IDEAS IN
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: CORRESPONDENT TO THEM, AND WHICH THEY EXACTLY REPRESENT.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of two kinds; but in each kind the phenomena are obvious, numerous, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: impression. From this constant conjunction of resembling perceptions
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: colour, or feel any sensation merely upon thinking of them. On the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: is constantly followed by an idea, which resembles it, and is only
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: SECT. VII. OF ABSTRACT IDEAS.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: A very material question has been started concerning ABSTRACT or GENERAL
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas, WHETHER THEY BE GENERAL OR PARTICULAR IN THE MIND'S CONCEPTION

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: account of every small alteration in its extension, duration and other
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: represents men of all sizes and all qualities; which it is concluded it
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: possible qualities, or by, representing no particular one at all. Now
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: it having been esteemed absurd to defend the former proposition, as
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the purposes of reflection and conversation.

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: SECT. VI. OF THE IDEA OF EXISTENCE, AND OF EXTERNAL EXISTENCE.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: It may not be amiss, before we leave this subject, to explain the ideas
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of existence and of external existence; which have their difficulties,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: as well as the ideas of space and time. By this means we shall be the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: better prepared for the examination of knowledge and probability, when
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: we understand perfectly all those particular ideas, which may enter into
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: our reasoning.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: There is no impression nor idea of any kind, of which we have any
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: consciousness or memory, that is not conceived as existent; and it
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: is evident, that from this consciousness the most perfect idea and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: assurance of being is derived. From hence we may form a dilemma, the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: most clear and conclusive that can be imagined, viz. that since we never
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: remember any idea or impression without attributing existence to it,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the idea of existence must either be derived from a distinct impression,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: conjoined with every perception or object of our thought, or must be the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: very same with the idea of the perception or object.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: As this dilemma is an evident consequence of the principle, that every
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: idea arises from a similar impression, so our decision betwixt the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: propositions of the dilemma is no more doubtful. So far from there being
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: any distinct impression, attending every impression and every idea,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that I do not think there are any two distinct impressions, which are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: inseparably conjoined. Though certain sensations may at one time be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: united, we quickly find they admit of a separation, and may be presented
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: apart. And thus, though every impression and idea we remember be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: considered as existent, the idea of existence is not derived from any
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: particular impression.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: The idea of existence, then, is the very same with the idea of what we
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: conceive to be existent. To reflect on any thing simply, and to reflect
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: on it as existent, are nothing different from each other. That idea,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: when conjoined with the idea of any object, makes no addition to it.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Whatever we conceive, we conceive to be existent. Any idea we please
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to form is the idea of a being; and the idea of a being is any idea we
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: please to form.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Whoever opposes this, must necessarily point out that distinct
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: impression, from which the idea of entity is derived, and must prove,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that this impression is inseparable from every perception we believe to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: be existent. This we may without hesitation conclude to be impossible.

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: PART III. OF KNOWLEDGE AND PROBABILITY.

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: we draw from the one to the other, and of the belief we repose in it?
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: SECT. III. WHY A CAUSE IS ALWAYS NECESSARY.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: To begin with the first question concerning the necessity of a cause:
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: It is a general maxim in philosophy, that whatever begins to exist, must
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: have a cause of existence. This is commonly taken for granted in all
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: reasonings, without any proof given or demanded. It is supposed to be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: founded on intuition, and to be one of those maxims, which though they
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: may be denyed with the lips, it is impossible for men in their hearts
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: really to doubt of. But if we examine this maxim by the idea of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: knowledge above-explained, we shall discover in it no mark of any such
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: intuitive certainty; but on the contrary shall find, that it is of a
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: nature quite foreign to that species of conviction.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: All certainty arises from the comparison of ideas, and from the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: discovery of such relations as are unalterable, so long as the ideas
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: continue the same. These relations are RESEMBLANCE, PROPORTIONS IN
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: QUANTITY AND NUMBER, DEGREES OF ANY QUALITY, and CONTRARIETY; none of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which are implyed in this proposition, Whatever has a beginning has
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: also a cause of existence. That proposition therefore is not intuitively
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: certain. At least any one, who would assert it to be intuitively
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: certain, must deny these to be the only infallible relations, and must
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: find some other relation of that kind to be implyed in it; which it will
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: then be time enough to examine.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: But here is an argument, which proves at once, that the foregoing
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: proposition is neither intuitively nor demonstrably certain. We can
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: never demonstrate the necessity of a cause to every new existence, or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: new modification of existence, without shewing at the same time the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: impossibility there is, that any thing can ever begin to exist without
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: some productive principle; and where the latter proposition cannot be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: proved, we must despair of ever being able to prove the former. Now that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the latter proposition is utterly incapable of a demonstrative proof,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: we may satisfy ourselves by considering that as all distinct ideas are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: separable from each other, and as the ideas of cause and effect are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: evidently distinct, it will be easy for us to conceive any object to be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: non-existent this moment, and existent the next, without conjoining to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: it the distinct idea of a cause or productive principle. The separation,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: therefore, of the idea of a cause from that of a beginning of existence,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: is plainly possible for the imagination; and consequently the actual
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: separation of these objects is so far possible, that it implies no
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: contradiction nor absurdity; and is therefore incapable of being refuted
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: by any reasoning from mere ideas; without which it is impossible to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: demonstrate the necessity of a cause.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Accordingly we shall find upon examination, that every demonstration,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which has been produced for the necessity of a cause, is fallacious and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: sophistical. All the points of time and place, say some philosophers
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: [Mr. Hobbes.], in which we can suppose any object to begin to exist, are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in themselves equal; and unless there be some cause, which is peculiar
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to one time and to one place, and which by that means determines and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: fixes the existence, it must remain in eternal suspence; and the object
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: can never begin to be, for want of something to fix its beginning. But I
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ask; Is there any more difficulty in supposing the time and place to be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: fixed without a cause, than to suppose the existence to be determined in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that manner? The first question that occurs on this subject is always,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: whether the object shall exist or not: The next, when and where it shall
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: begin to exist. If the removal of a cause be intuitively absurd in the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: one case, it must be so in the other: And if that absurdity be not clear
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: without a proof in the one case, it will equally require one in the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: other. The absurdity, then, of the one supposition can never be a proof
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of that of the other; since they are both upon the same footing, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: must stand or fall by the same reasoning.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: The second argument [Dr. Clarke and others.], which I find used on this
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: head, labours under an equal difficulty. Every thing, it is said, must
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ITSELF; that is, exist before it existed; which is impossible. But this
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: reasoning is plainly unconclusive; because it supposes, that in our
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: denial of a cause we still grant what we expressly deny, viz. that there
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: must be a cause; which therefore is taken to be the object itself; and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that, no doubt, is an evident contradiction. But to say that any thing
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: is produced, or to express myself more properly, comes into existence,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: without a cause, is not to affirm, that it is itself its own cause; but
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: on the contrary in excluding all external causes, excludes a fortiori
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the thing itself, which is created. An object, that exists absolutely
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: without any cause, certainly is not its own cause; and when you assert,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that the one follows from the other, you suppose the very point in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: questions and take it for granted, that it is utterly impossible any
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: thing can ever begin to exist without a cause, but that, upon the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: exclusion of one productive principle, we must still have recourse to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: another.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: has been employed to demonstrate the necessity of a cause. Whatever is
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

author: Hume, David

text: SECT. V. OF THE IMPRESSIONS OF THE SENSES AND MEMORY.

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: SECT. VII. OF THE NATURE OF THE IDEA OR BELIEF.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: The idea of an object is an essential part of the belief of it, but not
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the whole. We conceive many things, which we do not believe. In order
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: then to discover more fully the nature of belief, or the qualities of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: those ideas we assent to, let us weigh the following considerations.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: It is evident, that all reasonings from causes or effects terminate
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in conclusions, concerning matter of fact; that is, concerning the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: existence of objects or of their qualities. It is also evident, that the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: idea, of existence is nothing different from the idea of any object, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that when after the simple conception of any thing we would conceive
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: it as existent, we in reality make no addition to or alteration on our
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: first idea. Thus when we affirm, that God is existent, we simply
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: form the idea of such a being, as he is represented to us; nor is the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: existence, which we attribute to him, conceived by a particular idea,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which we join to the idea of his other qualities, and can again separate
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and distinguish from them. But I go farther; and not content with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: asserting, that the conception of the existence of any object is no
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: addition to the simple conception of it, I likewise maintain, that the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: belief of the existence joins no new ideas to those which compose
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the idea of the object. When I think of God, when I think of him as
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: existent, and when I believe him to be existent, my idea of him
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: neither encreases nor diminishes. But as it is certain there is a great
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: difference betwixt the simple conception of the existence of an object,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and the belief of it, and as this difference lies not in the parts or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: composition of the idea, which we conceive; it follows, that it must lie
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in the manner, in which we conceive it.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Suppose a person present with me, who advances propositions, to which I
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: do not assent, that Caesar dyed in his bed, that silver is more
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: fusible, than lead, or mercury heavier than gold; it is evident, that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: notwithstanding my incredulity, I clearly understand his meaning, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: form all the same ideas, which he forms. My imagination is endowed with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the same powers as his; nor is it possible for him to conceive any idea,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which I cannot conceive; nor conjoin any, which I cannot conjoin. I
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: therefore ask, Wherein consists the difference betwixt believing
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and disbelieving any proposition? The answer is easy with regard to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: propositions, that are proved by intuition or demonstration. In that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: case, the person, who assents, not only conceives the ideas according to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the proposition, but is necessarily determined to conceive them in that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: particular manner, either immediately or by the interposition of other
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas. Whatever is absurd is unintelligible; nor is it possible for the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: imagination to conceive any thing contrary to a demonstration. But as in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: reasonings from causation, and concerning matters of fact, this absolute
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: necessity cannot take place, and the imagination is free to conceive
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: both sides of the question, I still ask, Wherein consists the deference
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: betwixt incredulity and belief? since in both cases the conception of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the idea is equally possible and requisite.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: It will not be a satisfactory answer to say, that a person, who does not
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: assent to a proposition you advance; after having conceived the object
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in the same manner with you; immediately conceives it in a different
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: manner, and has different ideas of it. This answer is unsatisfactory;
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: not because it contains any falshood, but because it discovers not all
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the truth. It is contest, that in all cases, wherein we dissent from any
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: person, we conceive both sides of the question; but as we can believe
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: only one, it evidently follows, that the belief must make some
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: difference betwixt that conception to which we assent, and that from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which we dissent. We may mingle, and unite, and separate, and confound,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and vary our ideas in a hundred different ways; but until there appears
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: some principle, which fixes one of these different situations, we
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: have in reality no opinion: And this principle, as it plainly makes
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: no addition to our precedent ideas, can only change the manner of our
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: conceiving them.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: All the perceptions of the mind are of two kinds, viz. impressions and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas, which differ from each other only in their different degrees
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of force and vivacity. Our ideas are copyed from our impressions, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: represent them in all their parts. When you would any way vary the idea
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of a particular object, you can only encrease or diminish its force and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: vivacity. If you make any other change on it, it represents a different
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: object or impression. The case is the same as in colours. A particular
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: shade of any colour may acquire a new degree of liveliness or brightness
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: without any other variation. But when you produce any other variation,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: it is no longer the same shade or colour. So that as belief does nothing
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: but vary the manner, in which we conceive any object, it can only bestow
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: on our ideas an additional force and vivacity. An opinion, therefore,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: or belief may be most accurately defined, a lively idea related to or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: associated with a present impression.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: We may here take occasion to observe a very remarkable error, which
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: being frequently inculcated in the schools, has become a kind of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: establishd maxim, and is universally received by all logicians. This
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: error consists in the vulgar division of the acts of the understanding,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: into CONCEPTION, JUDGMENT and REASONING, and in the definitions we give
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of them. Conception is defind to be the simple survey of one or more
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas: Judgment to be the separating or uniting of different ideas:
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Reasoning to be the separating or uniting of different ideas by the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: interposition of others, which show the relation they bear to each
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: other. But these distinctions and definitions are faulty in very
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: considerable articles. For FIRST, it is far from being true, that in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: every judgment, which we form, we unite two different ideas; since in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that proposition, GOD IS, or indeed any other, which regards existence,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the idea of existence is no distinct idea, which we unite with that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of the object, and which is capable of forming a compound idea by the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: union. SECONDLY, As we can thus form a proposition, which contains only
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: one idea, so we may exert our reason without employing more than two
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas, and without having recourse to a third to serve as a medium
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: betwixt them. We infer a cause immediately from its effect; and this
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: inference is not only a true species of reasoning, but the strongest of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: all others, and more convincing than when we interpose another idea to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: connect the two extremes. What we may in general affirm concerning these
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: three acts of the understanding is, that taking them in a proper
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: light, they all resolve themselves into the first, and are nothing but
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: particular ways of conceiving our objects. Whether we consider a single
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: object, or several; whether we dwell on these objects, or run from them
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to others; and in whatever form or order we survey them, the act of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the mind exceeds not a simple conception; and the only remarkable
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: difference, which occurs on this occasion, is, when we join belief to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the conception, and are persuaded of the truth of what we conceive.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: This act of the mind has never yet been explaind by any philosopher; and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: therefore I am at liberty to propose my hypothesis concerning it; which
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: is, that it is only a strong and steady conception of any idea, and such
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: as approaches in some measure to an immediate impression. [Footnote 5.]
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: [Footnote 5. Here are the heads of those arguments, which
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

author: Hume, David

text: and vivacity; it follows upon the whole, that belief is a

text: according to the foregoing definition.]
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: This operation of the mind, which forms the belief of any matter of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: fact, seems hitherto to have been one of the greatest mysteries of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: philosophy; though no one has so much as suspected, that there was

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

text: SECT. XV. RULES BY WHICH TO JUDGE OF CAUSES AND EFFECTS.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: causes of any other; and no objects, which we can certainly determine in
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the same manner not to be the causes. Any thing may produce any thing.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Creation, annihilation, motion, reason, volition; all these may arise
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: from one another, or from any other object we can imagine. Nor will this
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: nothing hinders them from having that constant conjunction, on which the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: relation of cause and effect totally depends.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Since therefore it is possible for all objects to become causes or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: effects to each other, it may be proper to fix some general rules, by
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which we may know when they really are so.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: (1) The cause and effect must be contiguous in space and time.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: (2) The cause must be prior to the effect.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: (3) There must be a constant union betwixt the cause and effect. It is
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: chiefly this quality, that constitutes the relation.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: (4) The same cause always produces the same effect, and the same effect
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: never arises but from the same cause. This principle we derive from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: experience, and is the source of most of our philosophical reasonings.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: For when by any clear experiment we have discovered the causes or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: effects of any phaenomenon, we immediately extend our observation to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: every phenomenon of the same kind, without waiting for that constant
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: repetition, from which the first idea of this relation is derived.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: (5) There is another principle, which hangs upon this, viz. that where
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: several different objects produce the same effect, it must be by means
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of some quality, which we discover to be common amongst them. For as
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: like effects imply like causes, we must always ascribe the causation to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the circumstance, wherein we discover the resemblance.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: (6) The following principle is founded on the same reason. The
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: difference in the effects of two resembling objects must proceed from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that particular, in which they differ. For as like causes always
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: produce like effects, when in any instance we find our expectation to be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: disappointed, we must conclude that this irregularity proceeds from some
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: difference in the causes.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: (7) When any object encreases or diminishes with the encrease or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: diminution of its cause, it is to be regarded as a compounded effect,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: derived from the union of the several different effects, which arise
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: from the several different parts of the cause. The absence or presence
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of one part of the cause is here supposed to be always attended with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: As all the perceptions of the mind may be divided into impressions and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ideas, so the impressions admit of another division into original and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: secondary. This division of the impressions is the same with that which
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: I formerly made use of [Book I. Part I. Sect. 2.] when I distinguished
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: them into impressions of sensation and reflection. Original impressions
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: or impressions of sensation are such as without any antecedent
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: perception arise in the soul, from the constitution of the body, from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the animal spirits, or from the application of objects to the external
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: organs. Secondary, or reflective impressions are such as proceed from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: some of these original ones, either immediately or by the interposition
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of its idea. Of the first kind are all the impressions of the senses,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and all bodily pains and pleasures: Of the second are the passions, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: other emotions resembling them.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: It is certain, that the mind, in its perceptions, must begin somewhere;
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and that since the impressions precede their correspondent ideas, there
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: appearance in the soul. As these depend upon natural and physical
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: causes, the examination of them would lead me too far from my present
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: subject, into the sciences of anatomy and natural philosophy. For this
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: reason I shall here confine myself to those other impressions, which
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: I have called secondary and reflective, as arising either from the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: please to call it, without any preceding thought or perception. A fit of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: is not derived immediately from any affection or idea. The reflective
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: action, composition, and external objects. Of the second are the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: When we take a survey of the passions, there occurs a division of them
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: as proceed from the same principles, but by the conjunction of other
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: qualities. This distinction I cannot at present justify or explain any
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: pity, malice, generosity, with their dependants. And under the direct
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: passions, desire, aversion, grief, joy, hope, fear, despair and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: SECT. II OF PRIDE AND HUMILITY, THEIR OBJECTS AND CAUSES
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: The passions of PRIDE and HUMILITY being simple and uniform impressions,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: it is impossible we can ever, by a multitude of words, give a just
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: definition of them, or indeed of any of the passions. The utmost we
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: can pretend to is a description of them, by an enumeration of such
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: circumstances, as attend them: But as these words, PRIDE and humility,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: are of general use, and the impressions they represent the most common
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of any, every one, of himself, will be able to form a just idea of them,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: without any danger of mistake. For which reason, not to lose time upon
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: preliminaries, I shall immediately enter upon the examination of these
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: passions.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: It is evident, that pride and humility, though directly contrary, have
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: yet the same OBJECT. This object is self, or that succession of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: related ideas and impressions, of which we have an intimate memory and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: consciousness. Here the view always fixes when we are actuated by either
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of these passions. According as our idea of ourself is more or less
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: advantageous, we feel either of those opposite affections, and are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: elated by pride, or dejected with humility. Whatever other objects may
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: be comprehended by the mind, they are always considered with a view to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ourselves; otherwise they would never be able either to excite these
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: passions, or produce the smallest encrease or diminution of them. When
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: self enters not into the consideration, there is no room either for
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: pride or humility.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: But though that connected succession of perceptions, which we call SELF,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: be always the object of these two passions, it is impossible it can
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: be their CAUSE, or be sufficient alone to excite them. For as these
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: passions are directly contrary, and have the same object in common; were
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: their object also their cause; it coued never produce any degree of the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: one passion, but at the same time it must excite an equal degree of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the other; which opposition and contrariety must destroy both. It is
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: impossible a man can at the same time be both proud and humble; and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: where he has different reasons for these passions, as frequently
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: happens, the passions either take place alternately; or if they
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: encounter, the one annihilates the other, as far as its strength goes,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and the remainder only of that, which is superior, continues to operate
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: upon the mind. But in the present case neither of the passions coued
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ever become superior; because supposing it to be the view only of
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ourself, which excited them, that being perfectly indifferent to either,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: must produce both in the very same proportion; or in other words, can
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: produce neither. To excite any passion, and at the same time raise an
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: equal share of its antagonist, is immediately to undo what was done, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: must leave the mind at last perfectly calm and indifferent.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: We must therefore, make a distinction betwixt the cause and the object
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of these passions; betwixt that idea, which excites them, and that to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that as their ultimate and final object; but there is something farther
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the passions, and produces not both in the very same degree. The first
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: To begin with the causes of pride and humility; we may observe, that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

text: is himself, and the cause is the beautiful house: Which cause again is
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: this distinction.

text: SECT. VI LIMITATIONS OF THIS SYSTEM
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: But before we proceed farther in this subject, and examine particularly
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: all the causes of pride and humility, it will be proper to make some
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: PRIDE, AND DISAGREEABLE ONES, HUMILITY: And these limitations are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: derived from the very nature of the subject.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: I. Suppose an agreeable object to acquire a relation to self, the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: first passion, that appears on this occasion, is joy; and this passion
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: discovers itself upon a slighter relation than pride and vain-glory. We
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: may feel joy upon being present at a feast, where our senses are regard
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: with delicacies of every kind: But it is only the master of the feast,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: who, beside the same joy, has the additional passion of self-applause
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and vanity. It is true, men sometimes boast of a great entertainment,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: at which they have only been present; and by so small a relation convert
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: their pleasure into pride: But however, this must in general be owned,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that joy arises from a more inconsiderable relation than vanity, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that many things, which are too foreign to produce pride, are yet able
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to give us a delight and pleasure, The reason of the difference may be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: explained thus. A relation is requisite to joy, in order to approach
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the object to us, and make it give us any satisfaction. But beside this,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which is common to both passions, it is requisite to pride, in order
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to produce a transition from one passion to another, and convert the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: falsification into vanity. As it has a double task to perform, it must
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: be endowed with double force and energy. To which we may add, that where
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: agreeable objects bear not a very close relation to ourselves, they
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: commonly do to some other person; and this latter relation not only
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: excels, but even diminishes, and sometimes destroys the former, as we
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: shall see afterwards. [Part II. Sec. 4.]
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Here then is the first limitation, we must make to our general position,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that every thing related to us, which produces pleasure or pain,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: produces likewise pride or humility. There is not only a relation
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: required, but a close one, and a closer than is required to joy.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: II. The second limitation is, that the agreeable or disagreeable object
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: be not only closely related, but also peculiar to ourselves, or at least
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: common to us with a few persons. It is a quality observable in human
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: nature, and which we shall endeavour to explain afterwards, that
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: every thing, which is often presented and to which we have been
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: long accustomed, loses its value in our eyes, and is in a little
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: time despised and neglected. We likewise judge of objects more from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: comparison than from their real and intrinsic merit; and where we cannot
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: by some contrast enhance their value, we are apt to overlook even what
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: is essentially good in them. These qualities of the mind have an effect
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: upon joy as well as pride; and it is remarkable, that goods which are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: common to all mankind, and have become familiar to us by custom, give us
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: little satisfaction; though perhaps of a more excellent kind, than those
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: on which, for their singularity, we set a much higher value. But though
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: this circumstance operates on both these passions, it has a much greater
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: influence on vanity. We are rejoiced for many goods, which, on account
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of their frequency, give us no pride. Health, when it returns after a
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: long absence, affords us a very sensible satisfaction; but is seldom
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: regarded as a subject of vanity, because it is shared with such vast
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: numbers.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: The reason, why pride is so much more delicate in this particular than
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: joy, I take to be, as follows. In order to excite pride, there are
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which produces pleasure; and self, which is the real object of the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: passion. But joy has only one object necessary to its production, viz.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: that which gives pleasure; and though it be requisite, that this bear
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: some relation to self, yet that is only requisite in order to render it
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: agreeable; nor is self, properly speaking, the object of this passion.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Since, therefore, pride has in a manner two objects, to which it directs
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: our view; it follows, that where neither of them have any singularity,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the passion must be more weakened upon that account, than a passion,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: which has only one object. Upon comparing ourselves with others, as
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of these passions, and from the short duration of its connexion with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: small a part of our existence. It will be easy to comprehend the reason,

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: SECT. X OF PROPERTY AND RICHES
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: But the relation, which is esteemed the closest, and which of all others
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: produces most commonly the passion of pride, is that of property. This
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: relation it will be impossible for me fully to explain before I come
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to treat of justice and the other moral virtues. It is sufficient to
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: observe on this occasion, that property may be defined, such a relation
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: betwixt a person and an object as permits him, but forbids any other,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the free use and possession of it, without violating the laws of justice
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: and moral equity. If justice, therefore, be a virtue, which has a
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: natural and original influence on the human mind, property may be looked
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: upon as a particular species of causation; whether we consider the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: liberty it gives the proprietor to operate as he please upon the object
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: or the advantages, which he reaps from it. It is the same case, if
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: justice, according to the system of certain philosophers, should be
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: esteemed an artificial and not a natural virtue. For then honour, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: custom, and civil laws supply the place of natural conscience, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: produce, in some degree, the same effects. This in the mean time is
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: certain, that the mention of the property naturally carries our thought
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to the proprietor, and of the proprietor to the property; which being
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: a proof of a perfect relation of ideas is all that is requisite to our
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: present purpose. A relation of ideas, joined to that of impressions,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: always produces a transition of affections; and therefore, whenever any
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: pleasure or pain arises from an object, connected with us by property.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: we may be certain, that either pride or humility must arise from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: SECT. X OF RESPECT AND CONTEMPT
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: There now remains only to explain the passion of respect and contempt,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: along with the amorous affection, in order to understand all the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: passions which have any mixture of love or hatred. Let us begin with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: respect and contempt.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: In considering the qualities and circumstances of others, we may either
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: regard them as they really are in themselves; or may make a comparison
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: betwixt them and our own qualities and circumstances; or may join these
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: two methods of consideration. The good qualities of others, from the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: first point of view, produce love; from the second, humility; and from
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: the third, respect; which is a mixture of these two passions. Their
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: bad qualities, after the same manner, cause either hatred, or pride, or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: contempt, according to the light in which we survey them.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in respect, is, I think, too evident, from their very feeling or
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: appearance, to require any particular proof. That this mixture arises
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: from a tacit comparison of the person contemned or respected with
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: ourselves is no less evident. The same man may cause either respect,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: love, or contempt by his condition and talents, according as the person,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: who considers him, from his inferior becomes his equal or superior. In
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: changing the point of view, though the object may remain the same,
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: its proportion to ourselves entirely alters; which is the cause of an
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: alteration in the passions. These passions, therefore, arise from our
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: observing the proportion; that is, from a comparison.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: I have already observed, that the mind has a much stronger propensity
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: to pride than to humility, and have endeavoured, from the principles
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of human nature, to assign a cause for this phaenomenon. Whether my
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: in many instances. Among the rest, it is the reason why there is a much
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: greater mixture of pride in contempt, than of humility in respect, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: why we are more elevated with the view of one below us, than mortifyed
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: with the presence of one above us. Contempt or scorn has so strong a
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: tincture of pride, that there scarce is any other passion discernable:
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: Whereas in esteem or respect, love makes a more considerable ingredient
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: than humility. The passion of vanity is so prompt, that it rouzes at the
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: least call; while humility requires a stronger impulse to make it exert
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

text: itself.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: of humility, as well as love, while they belong to others, and are only
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: produce not always the mixt passions of respect and contempt.
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: I have supposed all along, that the passions of love and pride, and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

text: bestow a new force on all our thoughts and actions; while humility and
title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
author: Hume, David

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature

title: A Treatise of Human Nature
